Topic.Title: Why Amazon should buy EBAY.

Message.Msg: Interest rate is low. AMZN won't have problems to borrow money from banks. Ideally use 10% cash and 90% new issued AMZN shares. Since AMZN share has high value now, it is better to use AMZN shares not cash for acquisition. Could be 85%/15%, but no more than 20% cash.

Topic.Title: $350 AMZN by Jan of 2013. EPS $6.50 for 2013

Message.Msg: "If they don't spend that much. EPS is $4.50 this year. And We should see $6.75 next year and $9.50 by 2014" actually, we don't know that. As spending costs are capttalized to the balance sheet. More likely, these Fires sold were negative to earnings. I don't agree with your earnings forecasts, but the stock is so completely untethered to them that any price target might be possible, especially with Bernanke's QE escapade and the tight float support. It had a 25 multiple this AM on the day it would make $10 earnings a share: what we know is that AMZN has only been able to make $2.53/shr in the best 4 qtrs of earnings and that was not repeated.

Topic.Title: Why Amazon should buy EBAY.

Message.Msg: well they certainly would need to borrow alot or issue more shares to do it as their cash/liablilites is very low. Happens when you don't make money on your investments. I was surprised to see today that Kindle reader forecasts are nowhere near what they were projected to be just a couple years ago: ereader sales are now declining: the tablet space obviously affected that immensely.

Message.Title: I give credit to AMZN to here:
Message.Msg: they've been able to to get the stock to 250 on a giant support network that treats their sales gains better than they treat AAPL's profit gains. Not always that easy to drop those sales gains to the bottom line like AAPL has proven to be able to do. Yet, the stock performance is very similar to AAPL's over the past 3.5 years. Impressive support.
